section_header: 1. Purpose
field_label: By signing this form, you are agreeing that we may communicate with you through unsecured emails. This form identifies some of the risks of unsecured emails, provides guidelines for use, and documents your consent.

section_header: 2. Unsecured Email Risks.
field_label: Unsecured emails can be inadvertently misdirected by the sender or intentionally intercepted by third parties. The University of Minnesota cannot and does not guarantee the confidentiality of unsecured emails, nor is it responsible for unsecured emails that are lost due to technical failure during composition, transmission and/or storage.

section_header: 3. Privacy and Confidentiality.
field_label: Unsecured emails are not a secure method of communication. The content of an unsecured email may be viewed by any person who has access to your email account. Unsecured emails that you send us may be viewed by other staff depending on the nature and timing of your unsecured emails, and may be monitored by the University to ensure appropriate use. Unsecured emails may be viewed by your employer if you are using a work email account. Different University staff may view and process unsecured emails depending on the time of day you send them, or when your typical point of contact is not available. Communication by phone, postal mail, and secure email are considered secure. You should consider using these forms of communication.

section_header: 4. Content.
field_label: Unsecured emails should be used only for non-sensitive and non-urgent issues. You should limit the amount of health information in your unsecured emails to us to the minimum necessary.

section_header: 5. Ending Unsecured Email Communication.
field_label: This authorization does not have an expiration date. We may discontinue using unsecured emails as a means of communication with you by notifying you by unsecured email or letter. You may discontinue using unsecured emails as a means of communication by notifying us by e-mail to privacy@umn.edu or by letter to:Health Information Privacy & Compliance Office410 ChRC (MMC 501)426 Church Street SEMinneapolis, MN 55455.

section_header: 6. Authorizing Signature.
field_label: I am the research participant or personal representative authorized to act on behalf of the participant. I have read and understand the information regarding guidelines for unsecured email correspondence and had any questions answered to my satisfaction. By signing and providing my contact information below, I agree to communicate by unsecured emails using the email address below:

section_header: Directions:Â  Please answer each question by choosing yes or no. A few questions ask about several related types of behavior; please choose yes if any of these behaviors have ever been present. Although you may be uncertain about whether some behaviors were ever present or not, please answer yes or no to every question on the basis of what you think.
field_label: 1. Is she/he now able to talk using short phrases or sentences?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 2. Can you have a to and fro "conversation" with her/him that involves taking turns or building on what you have said?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 3. Has she/he ever used odd phrases or said the same thing over and over in almost exactly the same way (either phrases that she/he has heard other people use or ones that she/he made up)?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 4. Has she/he ever used socially inappropriate questions or statements? For example, has she/he ever regularly asked personal questions or made personal comments at awkward times?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 5. Has she/he ever got her/his pronouns mixed up (e.g., saying you or she/he for I)?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 6. Has she/he ever used words that she/he seemed to have invented or made up her/himself; put things in odd, indirect ways; or used metaphorical ways of saying things (e.g., saying hot rain for steam)?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 7. Has she/he ever said the same thing over in over in exactly the same way or insisted that you say the same thing over and over again?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 8. Has she/he ever had things that she/he seemed to have to do in a very particular order or rituals that she/he insisted that you go through?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 9. Has her/his facial expression seemed appropriate to the particular situation, as far as you could tell?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 10. Has she/he ever used your hand like a tool as if it were part of her/his own body (e.g., pointing with your finger, putting your hand on a doorknob to get you to open the door)?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 11. Has she/he ever had any interests that preoccupy her/him and might seem odd to other people (e.g., traffic lights, drainpipes, or timetables)?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 12. Has she/he ever seemed to be more interested in parts of a toy or an object (e.g., spinning wheels of a car), rather than using the object as it was intended?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 13. Has she/he ever had any special interests that were unusual in their intensity but otherwise appropriate for her/his age and peer group (e.g., trains, dinosaurs)?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 14. Has she/he ever seemed to be unusually interested in the feel, sound, taste, or smell of things or people?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 15. Has she/he ever had any mannerisms or odd ways of moving her/his hands or fingers, such as flapping or moving her/his fingers in front of her/his eyes?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 16. Has she/he ever had any complicated movements of her/his body, such as spinning or repeatedly bouncing up and down?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 17. Has she/he ever injured her/himself deliberately, such as by biting her/his arm or banging her/his head?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 18. Has she/he ever had any objects (other than a soft toy or comfort blanket) that she/he had to carry around?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 19. Does she/he have any particular friends or a best friend?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

section_header: For the following behaviors, please focus on the time period between the child's fourth and fifth birthdays. You may find it easier to remember how things were at the time by focusing on key events, such as starting school, moving houses, holidays, or other specific events that are particularly memorable for you as a family.Â
field_label: 20. When she/he was 4 to 5, did she/he ever talk with you just to be friendly (rather than to get something)?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 21. When she/he was 4 to 5, did she/he ever spontaneously copy you (or other people) or what you were doing (such as vacuuming, gardening, or mending things)?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 22. When she/he was 4 to 5, did she/he ever spontaneously point at things around her/him just to show you things (not just because she/he wanted them)?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 23. When she/he was 4 to 5, did she/he ever use gestures, other than pointing or pulling your hand, to let you know what she/he wanted?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 24. When she/he was 4 to 5, did she/he nod her/his head to mean yes ?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 25. When she/he was 4 to 5, did she/he shake her/his head to mean no ?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 26. When she/he was 4 to 5, did she/he usually look at you directly in the face when doing things with you or talking with you?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 27. When she/he was 4 to 5, did she/ he smile back if someone smiled at her/him?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 28. When she/he was 4 to 5, did she/he ever show you things that interested her/him to engage your attention?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 29. When she/he was 4 to 5, did she/he ever offer to share things other than food with you?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 30. When she/he was 4 to 5, did she/he ever seem to want you to join in her/his enjoyment of something?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 31. When she/he was 4 to 5, did she/he ever try to comfort you if you were sad or hurt?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 32. When she/he was 4 to 5, when she/he wanted something or wanted help, did she/he look at you and use gestures with sounds or words to get your attention?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 33. When she/he was 4 to 5, did she/he show a normal range of facial expressions?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 34. When she/he was 4 to 5, did she/he ever spontaneously join in and try to copy the actions in social games, such as The Mulberry Bush or London Bridge is Falling Down ?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 35. When she/he was 4 to 5, did she/he play any pretend or make-believe games?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 36. When she/he was 4 to 5, did she/he seem interested in other children of approximately the same age whom she/he did not know?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 37. When she/he was 4 to 5, did she/he respond positively when another child approached her/him?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 38. When she/he was 4 to 5, if you came into a room and started talking to her/him without calling her/his name, did she/he usually look up and pay attention to you?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 39. When she/he was 4 to 5, did she/he ever pay imaginative games with another child in such a way that you could tell that they each understood what the other was pretending?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: 40. When she/he was 4 to 5, did she/he play cooperatively in games that required joining in with a group of other children, such as hide-and-seek or ball games?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 0, No

field_label: Date of birth for subject of survey:

section_header: For each question, please select the choice that best describes your child's behavior over the past 6 months.
field_label: 1. Seems much more fidgety in social situations than when alone.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 2. Expressions on his/her face don't match what he/she is saying.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 3. Seems self-confident when interacting with others.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 4. When under stress, he or she shows rigid or inflexible patterns of behavior that seem odd.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 5. Doesn't recognize when someone is trying to take advantage of him or her.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 6. Would rather be alone than with others.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 7. Is aware of what others are thinking or feeling.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 8. Behaves in ways that seem strange or bizarre.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 9. Clings to adults, seems too dependent on them.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 10. Takes things too literally and doesn't get the real meaning of a conversation.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 11. Has good self-confidence.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 12. Is able to communicate his or her feelings to others.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 13. Is awkward in turn-taking interactions with peers (For example, doesn't seem to understand the give-and-take of conversations).
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 14. Is not well coordinated.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 15. Is able to understand the meaning of other people's tone of voice and facial expressions.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 16. Avoids eye contact or has unusual eye contact.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 17. Recognizes when something is unfair.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 18. Has difficulty making friends, even when trying his or her best.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 19. Gets frustrated trying to get ideas across in conversations.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 20. Shows unusual sensory interests (for example, mouthing or spinning objects) or strange ways of playing with toys.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 21. Is able to imitate others' actions.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 22. Plays appropriately with children his or her age.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 23. Does not join group activities unless told to do so.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 24. Has more difficulty than other children with changes in his or her routine.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 25. Doesn't seem to mind being out of step with or "not on the same wavelength" as others.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 26. Offers comfort to others when they are sad.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 27. Avoids starting social interactions with peers or adults.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 28. Thinks or talks about the same thing over and over.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 29. Is regarded by other children as odd or weird.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 30. Becomes upset in a situation with lots of things going on.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 31. Can't get his or her mind off something once he or she starts thinking about it.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 32. Has good personal hygiene.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 33. Is socially awkward, even when he or she is trying to be polite.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 34. Avoids people who want to be emotionally close to him or her.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 35. Has trouble keeping up with the flow of a normal conversation.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 36. Has difficulty relating to adults.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 37. Has difficulty relating to peers.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 38. Responds appropriately to mood changes in others (for example, when a friend's or playmate's mood changes from happy to sad).
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 39. Has an unusually narrow range of interests.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 40. Is imaginative, good at pretending (without losing touch with reality).
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 41. Wanders aimlessly from one activity to another.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 42. Seems overly sensitive to sounds, textures, or smells.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 43. Separates easily from caregivers.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 44. Doesn't understand how events relate to one another (cause and effect) the way other children his or her age do.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 45. Focuses his or her attention to where others are looking or listening.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 46. Has overly serious facial expressions.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 47. Is too silly or laughs inappropriately.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 48. Has a sense of humor, understands jokes.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 49. Does extremely well at a few tasks, but does not do as well at most other tasks.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 50. Has repetitive, odd behavior such as hand flapping or rocking.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 51. Has difficulty answering questions directly and ends up talking around the subject.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 52. Knows when he or she is talking too loud or making too much noise.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 53. Talks to people with an unusual tone of voice (for example, talks like a robot or like he or she is giving a lecture).
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 54. Seems to react to people as if they are objects.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 55. Knows when he or she is too close to someone or invading someone's space.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 56. Walks in between people two people who are talking.
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 1: Not true | 2, 2: Sometimes True | 3, 3: Often True | 4, 4: Almost Always True

field_label: 57. Gets teased a lot.

section_header:
Instructions: Here are some things parents might say about their children. Please tell us about your child and what he/she has been like in the past month. Read each item carefully, then mark how well it describes your child or how frequently it has happened in the past month.

0 = In the past month, this was not true at all about my child. It never (or seldom) happened.
1 = In the past month, this was just a little true about my child. It happened occasionally.
2 = In the past month, this was pretty much true about my child. It happened often (or quite a bit).
3 = In the past month, this was very much true about my child. It happened very often (very frequently).

Please choose only one answer for each item. It is important to respond to every item. For items that you find difficult to answer, please give it your best guess.

section_header: Caregiver Response Form
field_label: 1. Does the child have a permanent hearing loss?

If YES, please give further details

Note: CCC-2 is intended to be used with children who do not have a permanent hearing loss. If you have checked YES, please do not complete this form.
2. Does the child speak English as his or her primary language (the language the child speaks most frequently and is most comfortable using)?
Note: CCC-2 is intended to be used with children whose primary language is English. If you have checked NO, please do not complete this form.
3. Is the child able to put words together in sentences?
Note: CCC-2 is intended to be used with children can speak in simple sentences. If you have checked NO, please do not complete this form.

section_header: Information About the Person Completing the Caregiver Response Form
field_label:
How long have you known this child

Note: If you have not had regular contact with the child for at least three months, please do not complete this form.
Comments

The Children's Communication Checklist - Second Edition, U.S. Edition (CCC-2) was developed to gain a better understanding of children's communication strengths and difficulties in everyday settings.

Statements 1-50 refer to difficulties children may have that affect their ability to communicate. Please use the rating key provided to indicate how often you have observed the behavior by marking the circle under the correct rating option.

If you are uncertain of a rating, think over the last week and try to remember how often you have observed the child behaving this way.

Please read each item carefully. Do not leave any items blank.
1. Gets mixed up between he and she (e.g. says "he" when talking about a girl or "she" when talking about a boy)
select_choices_or_calculations:
0, Less than once a week (or never)
0 | 1, At least once a week, but not every day (or occasionally)
1 | 2, Once or twice a day (or frequently)
2 | 3, Several times (more than twice) a day (or always)
3

Please use the rating key provided to indicate how often you have observed the behavior by marking the circle under the correct rating option.

If you are uncertain of a rating, think over the last week and try to remember how often you have observed the child behaving this way.

field_label:
Kids sometimes have different feelings and ideas.

This form lists the feelings and ideas in groups. From each group of three sentences, pick one sentence that describes you best for the past two weeks. After you pick a sentence from the first group, go on to the next group.

There is no right or wrong answer. Just pick the sentence that best desribes the way you have been recently. Put a mark next to your answer. Put the mark in the circle next to the sentence that you pick.

section_header: Remember, for each group, pick out the sentence that describes you best in the PAST TWO WEEKS.

section_header: Thank you for your support of pediatric neurodevelopment research at [site_teach]!The following pages consist of surveys that ask questions about [stud_first] [stud_last]'s behavior, academic and social habits, and strengths in the classroom. Please answer all of the questions to the best of your ability - your responses are crucial data in our research. On average, the surveys take about 45 minutes to complete in total. It is recommended that you finish the surveys in one sitting. However, if you'd like to take a break please do so after hitting the 'submit' button at the bottom of the page. To return the to the surveys please click the original link sent to your email from the [site_teach]. You will be compensated for your time with a $25 gift card. Our study team may release generalized summary scores from the questionnaires. However, we will never share specific comments about the child. Please complete these surveys by [teach_due] If you have any questions or comments, someone on our study team will be happy to assist. Please contact us at [lab_number] or [lab_email].

field_note: As it pertains to Covid-19's impact on education

section_header:
Instructions: Here are some things teachers might say about their students. Please tell us about this student and what he/she has been like in the past month. Read each item carefully, then mark how well it describes this student or how frequently it has happened in the past month.

Â 

0 = In the past month, this was not true at all about this student. It never (or seldom) happened.

1 = In the past month, this was just a little true about this student. It happened occasionally.

2 = In the past month, this was pretty much true about this student. It happened often (or quite a bit).

3 = In the past month, this was very much true about this student. It happened very often (very frequently).

Â 

Please choose only one answer for each itme. It is important to respond to every item. For items that you find difficult to answer, please give your best guess.

section_header:
Instructions

This survey contains statements describing a student's behavior and level of academic performance. It consists of three parts: Social Skills, Problem Behaviors, and Academic Competence.Â 

Social Skills & Problem Behaviors

Please read each item and think about this student's behavior during the past two months. Then, decide how often the student displays the behavior.Â 

If this student never exhibits the behavior, select theÂ N

If this student seldom exhibits the behavior, select theÂ S

If this student often exhibits the behavior, select theÂ O

If this student almost always exhibits the behavior, select the A

For each of the Social Skills items, please also rate how important you think the behavior is for success in your classroom.Â 

If you think the behavior is not important for success in your classroom, select theÂ n

If you think the behavior is important for success in your classroom, select theÂ iÂ 

If you think the behavior is critical for success in your classroom, select theÂ c

Academic Competence

Please assess this student's academic or learning behaviors in your classroom. Compare this student with other students in the same classroom.Â 

Mark all items using a scale of 1 to 5. Mark "1" if this student is in the lowest 10% of the class. Mark "5" if this student is in the highest 10% of the class.Â 

Please answer every item

In some cases, you may not have observed this student perform a particular behavior. If you are uncertain of your response to an item, give your best estimate. There are no right or wrong answers.Â

section_header: This questionnaire will allow us to have a better understanding of the sleep-wake rhythm of your child and any problems in his/her sleep behavior. Try to answer every question; in answering, consider each question pertaining to the PAST 6 MONTHS of the child's life.
field_label: How many hours of sleep does your child get on most nights?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, 9-11 hours | 2, 8-9 hours | 3, 7-8 hours | 4, 5-7 hours | 5, Less than 5 hours

field_label: How long after going to bed does your child usually fall asleep?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Less than 15 minutes| 2, 15-30 minutes | 3, 30-45 minutes | 4, 45-60 minutes | 5, More than 60 minutes

field_label: The child goes to bed reluctantly.

field_label: Notes

section_header:
Instructions: Please read carefully before starting:

Below you will see a set of statements that describe children's reactions to a number of situations. We would like you to tell us what your child's reaction is likely to be in those situations. There are of course no "correct" ways of reacting; children differ widely in their reactions, and it is these differences we are trying to learn about. Please read each statement and decide whether it is a "true" or "untrue" description of your child's reaction within the past six months.Â 

See the sample question below:
field_label: Choose the number that corresponds with how true the statement is. See example below:

section_header:
If you cannot answer one of the items because you have never seen the child in that situation, for example, if the statement is about the child playing wildly and recklessly and you have never seen your child play that way, then choose 'Does not apply".

Please be sure to respond by choosing a number or "Does not apply" for every item. If you find an item objectionable or upsetting, you may make an exception to this instruction and skip the item.

section_header:
For each item listen below, how does this child compare to other children of the same age? Please select the best rating based on your observations over the past month.

Below is a list of statements. Please read each statement very carefully and rate how strongly you agree or disagree with it by selecting your answer.

section_header: The Broad Autism Phenotype Questionnaire
field_label: Instructions You are about to fill out a series of statements related to personality and lifestyle. For each question, select the answer that best describes how often that statement applies to you. Many of these questions ask about your interactions with other people. Please think about the way you are with most people, rather than special relationships you may have with spouses or significant others, children, siblings, and parents. Everyone changes over time, which can make it hard to fill out questions about personality. Think about the way you have been the majority of your adult life, rather than the way you were as a teenager, or times you may have felt different than normal. You must answer each question, and give only one answer per question. If you are confused, please give your best guess.
1. I like being around other people
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Very rarely | 2, Rarely | 3, Occasionally | 4, Somewhat often | 5, Often | 6, Very often

section_header:
Please rate this person's behavior by reading each of the items listed and then choosing the score that best describes how much of a problem the item is for the person. Be sure to read and score all items listed. Make your ratings based on your observations and interactions with the person over the last month. Use the definitions in the description below to score each item.

Â 

0 = behavior does not occur

1 = behavior occurs and is a mild problem

2 = behavior occurs and is a moderate problem

3 = behavior occurs and is a severe problem

Â 

When deciding on a score for each item, consider: (a) how frequently the behavior occurs (e.g., weekly versus hourly), (b) how difficult it is to interrupt the behavior (e.g., can be easily redirected versus becomes distressed if interrupted) and (c) how much the behavior interferes with ongoing events (e.g., easy to ignore versus very disruptive).
field_label: Have you read the instructions?
select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Yes | 2, No

section_header: Instructions: Listed below are items concerning behaviors or problems sometimes experienced by adults. Read each item carefully and decide how much or how frequently each item describes your child's other biological parent recently. Indicate your response for each item by circling the number that corresponds to your choice. Use the following scale: 0 = Not at all, never; 1 = Just a little, once in awhile; 2 = Pretty much, often; and 3 = Very much, very frequently.
